docs.lead_paragraph: Summit Bancorp, New Jersey's largest bank, has agreed to acquire privately held Madison Consulting Group, expanding its employee-benefit insurance business. With the acquisition, Summit, which has $32 billion in assets and branches in New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania, will represent most of the region's major health insurance companies and manage more than $375 million in annual health insurance premiums for clients.
docs.abstract: Summit Bancorp, New Jersey's largest bank, agrees to acquire privately held Madison Consulting Group (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A powerful Republican senator dropped his opposition today to President Clinton's choice to head the Food and Drug Administration, clearing the way for the Senate to approve the nomination before adjourning. The agency has become one of the most influential in the Federal Government, responsible for assuring the safety of drugs, medical devices, food and cosmetics for millions of Americans.

headline.main: Nomination for F.D.A. Post Nears Approval in Senate

docs.abstract: Sen Don Nickles drops his opposition to Pres Clinton's choice of Dr Jane E Henney to head Food and Drug Administration, clearing way for Senate to approve nomination before adjourning; Nickles, abortion opponent, acts after winning assurances from Henney and Health Sec Donna E Shalala on abortion issues; Henney has also pledged to carry out changes approved by Congress to modernize agency; House approves spending bill that includes $34 million to help FDA enforce ban on tobacco sales to children (M)
docs.snippet: A powerful Republican senator dropped his opposition today to President Clinton's choice to head the Food and Drug Administration, clearing the way for the Senate to approve the nomination before adjourning.    The agency has become one of the most...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Grenade Attack Imperils Mideast Peace Efforts President Clinton struggled to salvage the Middle East peace talks in Maryland after a Palestinian grenade attack on civilians in Israel led Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to declare that he was limiting discussion to security issues. A1 The attack on a busy bus terminal in Beersheba during the morning rush hour wounded 67 people. A12 Terror in Indonesia Hysteria has been sweeping some remote parts of Indonesia, where people are so terrified of black magic that groups are forming daily to seize, torture and execute anyone suspected of being a sorcerer. At least 150 people have died. A1 German Rejects Offer Chancellor-elect Gerhard Schroder's choice for Economics Minister, Jost Stollmann, turned down the position. The rejection is the strongest sign that the incoming Government will be more left-wing than pragmatic. A3 Mr. Schroder plans to meet with top industrial executives to discuss options for resolving the growing number of lawsuits over Hitler's use of slave labor. The move is an indication that the new Government may be willing to help set up a compensation fund. A3 Vote on Gay Nominee Denied The Senate leadership has effectively killed the nomination of James C. Hormel to be Ambassador to Luxembourg, even though he had received broad bipartisan support in the Senate. Congressional officials agreed that he might well have been confirmed for the post had there been a vote. The appointment would have made him the first openly gay American ambassador. A12 Pinochet to Fight Madrid Trial Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator detained in London for extradition hearings, indicated that he would resolutely oppose any attempt to try him in Madrid, as a Spanish judge broadened genocide charges against him. A14 More Tensions in Kosovo The Yugoslav Army deployed two battalions of soldiers, tanks and artillery in Kosovo Province after reports that three Serbian police officers had been killed, Western diplomats said. A14 Leftist Gains Majority in Italy Massimo D'Alema, a former Communist who leads the country's largest leftist party, brokered a majority by forging alliances with a breakaway faction of Communists and a small center-right party. Given the composition of the majority, some see it as destined to make political compromises with the Vatican. A9 Nigerian Fire Death Toll Rises The death toll has reached at least 500 in the fire that engulfed hundreds of people scavenging for gasoline from a ruptured pipeline in southern Nigeria, witnesses and medical workers said. A5 World Briefing A8 NATIONAL A16-28 Federal Spending Bill To Be Voted On Today Lawmakers hurriedly hammered out policy issues like the banning of poison gas and the financing of more home care for the elderly, putting the final punctuation in the $500 billion spending bill needed to keep the Government open. A final vote is scheduled for today. A1 Backlash as an Issue A Democratic poll found that Jay Inslee, a Democrat in Washington State running for the House, had gained ground since he became the first, and only, Democrat in a tight race to run a commercial criticizing his opponent for voting for a broad impeachment inquiry. A24 More Jones Case Documents A Federal judge in Little Rock, Ark., made public hundreds of pages of documents from the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit against President Clinton. Ms. Jones's lawyers will ask an appeals court today to reinstate her suit, which the District Court dismissed on April 1. A24 Housing Investigation Widens The nation's chief housing investigator has broadened an inquiry into possible fraud in housing-assistance programs to include Long Island and other locales, in response to criticism that she was driven by racial and political considerations. A28 Fires Hit Colorado Ski Area Fires erupted along a mile-long mountain ridge in Vail, Colo., destroying three major buildings and damaging four chair lifts near the site of a disputed ski area expansion into national parkland. A16 Killings Jolt a Tourist Spot Santa Monica, Calif., which recorded one homicide in 1997, has been rocked by three killings in a week, including the shooting of a German tourist during a street robbery. A16 After the Flood, in Texas The authorities in Houston continued to search for three children swept away by flood waters during weekend storms that killed 14 people in Texas. Nearly a fourth of the state, or 60 counties, has experienced flooding, officials said. A16 Doctors' H.M.O. Rebellion More than 400 doctors in Dallas have terminated their contracts with Aetna's H.M.O., and Aetna has retaliated by cutting access to patients. A18 A Year in the Arctic A Canadian icebreaker, completing a yearlong research project in the Arctic Ocean, has reached Prudhoe Bay, Alaska, with a rich cargo of data on what drives changes in the world's climate. A19 Concerns for Glenn Flight Safety concerns have arisen over the shuttle flight that will carry Senator John Glenn back into space on Oct. 29, mainly because no shuttle has been launched for nearly five months. Safety experts say the shuttles must fly regularly to keep machinery and launching crews in good order. A26 NEW YORK/REGION B1-16 Man, 20, Goes on Trial In Killing of Teacher Opening statements were given in the murder trial of Corey Arthur, who is accused of torturing, robbing and killing his former high school English teacher, Jonathan M. Levin, the son of Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner. B1 Marchers Scuffle With Police A march on Fifth Avenue to protest the killing of a gay student in Wyoming ended with 60 arrests and several injuries, after demonstrators scuffled with police officers. B1 Traffic Agent Killed by Taxi A traffic enforcement agent was fatally injured when his Police Department scooter was struck by a taxi on the Upper West Side. City records showed that the cab driver had nine moving vehicle violations and three speeding convictions. Even though fault had not been determined, senior advisers to Mayor Giuliani said the crash underscored the need for rules to hasten the revocation of the licenses of taxi drivers with repeated violations. B3 D'Amato Measure Faces Repeal Congress is expected to repeal a provision on Freddie Mac mortgage insurance that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato got inserted into an appropriations bill that passed two weeks ago. Eight companies that control the mortgage insurance business object to the measure. Freddie Mac officials and Mr. D'Amato said contributions to Mr. D'Amato's campaign had nothing to do with his efforts on the home loan mortgage corporation's behalf. B5 SCIENCE TIMES F1-12 Health & Fitness F7-12 ARTS E1-10 SPORTSTUESDAY D1-8 Tyson Can Fight Again The Nevada State Athletic Commission restored Mike Tyson's boxing license, 15 months after it revoked it because he bit Evander Holyfield's ears in a heavyweight title bout. A1 Rebuff to N.B.A. Players An arbitrator ruled that N.B.A. players with guaranteed contracts need not be paid during the lockout. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-22 U.S. Attacks Gates's Credibility The Federal antitrust trial against Microsoft opened with a pointed personal attack on the credibility and integrity of William H. Gates. A Microsoft spokesman said evidence cited in the Government's presentation was taken out of context. A1 The written testimony of Netscape's chief executive supplies new details of a disputed meeting between Microsoft and Netscape. C4 Building a Supermarket Giant Kroger said it would acquire Fred Meyer in a deal to create a supermarket giant with $43 billion in revenue and 2,200 stores in 31 states. C1 Stocks Continue Their Advance Stock prices moved higher for the sixth time in seven sessions. The Dow was up 49.69 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,466.45. Broader market measures also gained. C1 Administering the Internet The Clinton Administration is expected to commit to handing over administration of the Internet to a nonprofit corporation. C1 Business Digest C1 FASHION B10-11 OBITUARIES B9 EDITORIAL A30-31 Editorials: Arrest of General Pinochet; grass-roots message on reform; tense times at Mideast summit; plundering a municipal union. Columns: Anthony Lewis. Crossword E7 Weather C21 Public Lives B2

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigned with Representative Charles E. Schumer for the second time in a month today, assailing Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for deluging Mr. Schumer with a ''blizzard of negative advertising,'' and she explicitly urged women to support the Democratic challenger in November. ''If you look at the records of these two men -- and they've both been in public life, so we don't have to guess -- there is absolutely no choice,'' Mrs. Clinton declared at a fund-raiser for the Brooklyn Congressman in Manhattan this morning. ''Al D'Amato does not deserve the votes of the women in New York -- he has consistently voted against so many issues that women care about, that we think about.''

headline.main: Back Schumer, Hillary Clinton Tells Women Voters

docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigns with Representative Charles E Schumer for second time in month, assailing Senator Alfonse M D'Amato for deluging Schumer with 'blizzard of negative advertising,'; she explicitly urges women to support Schumer in November election; D'Amato, campaigning in New Rochelle, discusses his efforts to raise money for breast cancer research as part of support for Defense Department appropriations bill; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Middle Eastern oil emirates are the classic one-commodity economies. When oil prices boom, the sheiks build hospitals and air-conditioned palaces, buy fighter jets and import tens of thousands of service workers. When oil prices sink, the hospitals crumble, the service workers are sent home and wrecks of Mercedes rust in the sand. Manhattan is America's Qatar, but it specializes in paper instead of oil. When the markets boom, youthful bankers in handmade shirts and English shoes chug-a-lug Chateau Margaux, governments go on binges of borrowing and building, and service workers from all around the world crowd into the city.

headline.main: In Terms of Jobs, A One-Street Town

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by financial consultant, Charles R Morris, says New York City economy should be less dependent on concentration of jobs and payrolls in securities industry to better weather stock market crashes; notes at end of 1997 security industry employment accounted for 5.5 percent of city's jobs--up from 5.3 percent in 1987--and staggering 19.3 percent of city payrolls; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the biggest rebellion yet against a health insurance company, more than 400 doctors in Dallas have terminated their contracts with Aetna Inc.'s health maintenance organization, and Aetna has retaliated by cutting off their access to all its Dallas patients. As a result, nearly 30,000 patients covered by Aetna must accept doctors who remain under contract to the company. If the patients choose to remain with the insurgent doctors, they face paying them cash for their care, at least for the three or four months it will take the patients to sign up with other companies.

headline.main: 400 Doctors in Dallas Break Contracts With Aetna's H.M.O.

docs.abstract: More than 400 doctors in Dallas, in biggest rebellion yet against health insurance company, terminate contracts with Aetna Inc's health maintenance organization; Aetna retaliates by cutting off their access to all its Dallas patients; nearly 30,000 patients covered by Aetna, as result, must accept doctors who remain under contract to company; if patients choose to remain with insurgent doctors, they face paying them cash for care--at least for three or four months it will take to sign up with other companies (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of Medicare beneficiaries being dropped from health maintenance organizations have suddenly found themselves in a confusing predicament, with no reliable information about their options and no guarantee of coverage for costly prescription drugs. Moreover, the Clinton Administration and the health insurance industry disagree over the rights and protections available to such Medicare beneficiaries, who receive a bewildering variety of conflicting information when they try to buy private insurance to supplement Medicare.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Cut Off Medicare, Leaving Many in Quandary

docs.abstract: Tens of thousands of Medicare beneficiaries being dropped from health maintenance organizations find themselves in confusing predicament, with no reliable information about their options and no guarantee of coverage for costly prescription drugs; predicament is compounded by disagreement between Clinton Administration and health insurance industry over rights and protections available to such beneficiaries, who receive bewildering variety of conflicting information while trying to buy private insurance to supplement Medicare; Federal officials acknowledge that their interpretation of Medicare law would not necessarily be accepted by all companies that sell insurance to fill in gaps in Medicare, known as Medigap insurance; many such companies, regulated primarily by states, say they are unfamiliar with new obligations to consumers under Federal law, as interpreted by Administration (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Americans are looking for a good prescription to cure the ills of health care, but it is too late this year to resuscitate two of the most important public health measures considered by this or any Congress.
docs.abstract: American Academy of Family Physicians president Dr Lanny R Copeland letter on Oct 18 article deplores Congressional failure to approve bill to help curb tobacco use and bill to define standard covering emergency medical care and requiring internal and external appeals process for beneficiaries and full benefits information for health plan enrollees (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Americans are looking for a good prescription to cure the ills of health care, but it is too late this year to resuscitate two of the most important public health measures considered by this or any Congress.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Mideast Peace Talks Continue Past Deadline Talks with Israeli and Palestinian leaders on an interim peace accord will continue past their original deadline and into today, despite more than 20 hours of personal involvement by President Clinton, American officials announced. A1 Arrest May Set Precedent Judge Baltasar Garzon, the Spanish magistrate who succeeded in getting Scotland Yard to arrest Chile's former dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, has suddenly moved closer to creating an important legal precedent, one that could make the retirement of former dictators decidedly uncomfortable. A1 General Pinochet remained sequestered under police guard in London, awaiting a potentially devastating court hearing to weigh his extradition on charges of genocide, terrorism and murder. British officials have not said where General Pinochet is. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Mark Nielsen campaigns, he often introduces himself as the Republican running for John G. Rowland's old Congressional seat. No matter that Mr. Rowland, now the Governor, hasn't been in Congress since 1990, and that there have been two Congressmen in the seat since then. Mr. Nielsen, who calls himself a ''John Rowland Republican,'' is the challenger in a competitive race for Fifth District Congressman. He is blunt about seeking to benefit from any coattails the popular governor might offer and any association with Mr. Rowland that would entice voters to cast ballots for him, instead of for the Democratic incumbent James H. Maloney.

headline.main: Coattails And More In the Races For Congress

docs.abstract: Article on competition between Republican Mark Nielsen and Democratic incumbent James H Maloney for Fifth Congesssional District seat in Connecticut; photos; map (M)
